questions.question_text: Which of the following Windows OS technologies is used to store remote data accessed via a WAN connection on local servers for user access?

discussion.content: Process of elimination nailed this one. The most logical answer is A. Furthermore, BranchCache allows computers at a local branch office to cache data from a file or web server on a WAN (wide area network). The data can be cached either on the client computers, in distributed cache mode, or on a local server, in hosted cache mode.

BranchCache (per Schmidt)
Wide area network (WAN) links are slower than local area network (LAN) connections. This is because WANs connect buildings, locations in different cities, or locations in different countries. Microsoft has introduced a technology called BranchCache that helps users more quickly retrieve data from remote locations. BranchCache is available on Windows 7, 8, and 10 and some Windows Server versions. The beauty of BranchCache is that whenever a user accesses content from a remote server or cloud server, that information is stored locally. The next time the user needs to access that content, the information is
retrieved faster and without using WAN resources. If another user needs that same information, that user retrieves it from the local storage and doesn’t use WAN resources either. Only authorized users can access the information, so even though it is stored locally, it is secure.
No Doubt, BranchCache is the correct.

comments.content: Useless information

discussion.content: I thought it was Proxy server

choices.C: Joe's hotspot gave him an invalid IP address
choices.B: Someone else is using Joe's hotspot due to weak password
choices.D: Joe is likely in a poor signal area and should try another area
choices.A: Joe should be using WEP security on his hotspot for faster throughput

discussion.content:
A weak password is the most correct answer. Note that Ann is using her own hotspot instead of Joe's. Nearby parties interested enough could guess an easy password like that.
Using WEP is incorrect; WEP is less secure than WPA2.
Invalid IP address is incorrect; Joe would be unable to browse at all.
Poor signal area is incorrect, but a good answer; Ann would also be experiencing similar issues.

comments.content: True if using personal accounts but if they are using company devices or accounts then they will use standardised vendors. This isn't mentioned either way in the question so is not the most likely problem to consider.
Not necessarily with the poor signal they could be on different networks and Ann's is stronger
It doesn't said that she is at the same spot at the moment though.

discussion.content: this is possible b or d what weird choices of answer. even a normal person can't guess the password as a hotspot unless your there at a coffee shop 24/7 someone could try.

discussion.content: The answer picked here refers to a "local power user account", but Windows 10 doesn't have power user accounts, it has "Administrator" and "Standard User" accounts. So I'm not certain if this is the correct answer.

The correct answer here is A. DISM may sound like a sensible tool but why would anything to do with the power user account solve this problem? The user's settings have been reset and files/mapped drives are not appearing, this points towards a corrupted user profile. The steps to rebuild the profile are to delete the registry entry for the user and to delete or rename to user's folder then reboot and log in again. Once you log in again the profile will be automatically rebuilt and you can transfer back any files from the renamed folder (as long as you didn't delete it). As vapoodlized said this is covered in Professor Messer's videos on troubleshooting in some detail, however the profile has not yet been deleted as he suggested, that is what you need to do to fix the problem.

Power Users group doesn’t have any special permissions in Windows 10, option A wouldn’t be a valid solution to the problem.The issue at hand is that a user logs into a machine and notices that shared drives are missing, the My Documents folder is empty, and personal settings are reset. This suggests a problem with the user’s profile, not the Windows image itself.The most appropriate answer would be B
"re-add the power user account" So that would imply that it existed before. I'm guessing this question is old and referring to an older Windows. Probably C is correct then.

Selected Answer: A
I think the answer is A, power users arent even a thing anymore

C is the more best answer as: Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) is a command-line tool that is used to mount and service Windows images before deployment. You can use DISM image management commands to mount and get information about Windows image (. wim) files or virtual hard disks (VHD). Dism command can also runs a scan for corruption and repairs problems that it finds with the operating system you are logged into.
A is the correct answer cause the PC opened a temporally account, you must delete the temp account using REG EDIT registry on the local account

comments.content: Messer has a similar question in his practice exams where the answer is to rename the user's folder and delete their profile in the registry. Therefore, A should be the correct answer.
It's obvious that you didn't watch professor Messer's videos :)
It will be recreated during login attempt. Profiles sometimes have to be recreated for troubleshoot but not in this case.
If the profile has been deleted, how are they logging in?

discussion.content:
C is the correct answer. Since the term "Power user" isn't used anymore (made obsolete in Windows Vista), references to power users in modern terms can be equated to standard users. It will most likely be worded differently on the actual exam to fix this confusion.

The question is referring to rebuilding a user account after the account has already been deleted (Messer goes over this entire process). You should know that there's an issue with the user's profile from logging in and not having their files, so the profile has already been deleted and they are in the stage of rebuilding.
A. is not correct because this takes part during the deletion stage.
B. is not correct for the same reason as A.
D. is not where user profiles are managed.

Refer to Messer's "Troubleshooting Solutions" video for 1002.
Crossing my fingers that the question has the operating system wrong... because Windows 10 doesn't have power users, but DISM seems the way to go

...Windows 10 no longer uses "power user" accounts.....

Is this CompTIA or is this the person typing in the questions/answers from memory?
whats the correct answer?

comments.content: But according the link then A is also correct
the link doesnt mention anything about re adding local power users though?

discussion.content:
i think the answer is correct

see solution #3 from this link
https://windowsreport.com/corrupt-user-profile-windows-10/

If the Os was Win7 , you can create a different user and then rename it with the bad users profile it will apply the fix, however, here looks like Win10 whereas you have to modify the Registry to apply the fix.Hence, A looks good to me.
https://www.tenforums.com/tutorials/48012-fix-youve-been-signed-temporary-profile-windows-10-a.html is what my company's consultant used.

comments.content: renaming a user folder breaks the SID and Guid in the registry and causes a temp profile issue. If these are the registry entries mentioned, then deleting them and renaming the user folder would only create a new user folder when the user logs on.

discussion.content: If I remember correctly, the answer should be "A" as told to me from a technician my previous company was using. For awhile, we had this issue on several computers over a few months and that was the fix he applied.

questions.question_text:
A user who is running Windows 10 logs into a machine and notices that shared drives are missing, the `My Documents` folder is empty, and personal settings are reset.
Which of the following would be required to resolve the issue?

choices.D: Remove the user account in Credential Manager and restart the PC
choices.A: Remove the registry entry and rename the local account folder
choices.C: Run DISM and re-add the local power user account
choices.B: Delete or rename the local user folder

choices.A: Politely ask the user to call back
choices.B: Ask another technician to take the call
choices.C: Troubleshoot the issue for the user
choices.E: Put the user on hold and troubleshoot after the scheduled break
choices.D: Input the issue as a ticket and escalate to Tier 2

questions.question_text:
A technician is working at a help desk firm and receives a call from a user who has experienced repeated BSODs. The technician is scheduled to take a break just after the call comes in.
Which of the following is the BEST choice for the technician to make?

comments.content: Don't spit on free points, some of us need them XD
This is that "softskills" thing they talk about
well sometimes we need some funny jokes from COMPTIA

discussion.content: This question is just dumb
F, ignore the call and go straight to break

comments.content: LooooL

discussion.content: I've seen this dumb question... its C

The best choice for the technician to make is C. Troubleshoot the issue for the user. This choice demonstrates professionalism, customer service, and problem-solving skills, which are essential for a help desk technician.

If you are a helpdesk geek who just answers calls, you probably want to escalate that to tier 2. CompTIA doesn't mention anything about managing your brakes, but it puts a very high focus on getting that ticket registered into your system. - It mentions escalating issues as well.

If this is a real exam question then I hope CompTIA does give some kind of points for C, because it feels like in some situations this may be the most professional thing to do. Answer and get it logged into the system so the issue gets looked at quicker, rather than B, because what if another technician is on a call?

Saying that the reason why I do agree B is the most correct answer because the question does not state that any other additional information. Plus the key word is Tier 2, so maybe the expectation is it gets looked at before being escalated. In a normal situation, you just communicate to your colleague to take the customer.

comments.content: On help desk jobs everybody has a scheduled break. If you spent your 15 minutes break to help the costumer, than you will end up to take your break while someone else scheduled for their break. So, everyone should stick with their work and break schedules .

discussion.content:
If he wants to keep his job the "BEST choice for the technician to make?"
C. To take the call
Let me find someone else, I'm on break... doesn't sound right
What if the other technician is busy

I feel as if the corporate answer would be C: Troubleshoot the issue for the user, but what should be the correct issue for all involved is B: Ask another tech to take take over the call. That said, it depends on the situation in which you are working. If you're in a call center, typically when you're about to go on break, the system is setup for you to deactivate/disengage, preventing you from entering into another call. If you're working in a store/repair environment, one where you're typically walking around, working directly with customers hands on, answering calls as they come in, you'd either not answer the call since you're going on break, or if you're currently the only one who can answer the call (which is unlikely) you'd take the call, and then say, "Let me pass you to an available technician who can assist you." or something more professionally polite along those lines.
To me the answer should be "C," but if you really need the break at that time then "B." I would fix they're problem then take my break after that call.

the technician as a scheduled break before the call, he as the right to that, however the user who had a repeated issue would need more attention, so its best the technician hands the call to another who isnt due for a break.

comments.content: Im a helpdesk tech, and while b is an answer sometimes, this question is dumb because like 99% of the time even if there is more than 1 of you on shift, the other is also on a call. C is the best answer, or even better make c and b part of the same answer, such as pass the call if possible and if not take the call and do your break later etc

discussion.content: B is actually correct. I work in a data center and we are suppose to be available to assist customers 24/7 so when I am working with other techs, we have to have set lunches and breaks that way someone is always available up front to take calls or solve tickets. C would be an acceptable answer if you were scheduled alone during a shift.

comments.content: It wouldn't count against you....But the cert does cover professionalism and stuff like that I think. Not exactly sure where in the course objectives....But it's all over the beginnings of the study material...which I also sorta ..skimmed through.

questions.question_text:
A technician accessed a network share from a computer joined to workgroup. The technician logged in as `user1` and directed the computer to save the username and password. Several weeks later, the technician wants to log in to this network share using the administrator account. The computer does not prompt for a username and password, but it automatically logs in to the network share under the `user1` account.
Which of the following would allow the technician to log in using the `administrator` username?
